block.p: Barak Sees Bleak Future Without Peace Settlement Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned of ''a tragedy'' ahead for Israel and the Palestinians if they failed to reach a peace pact, and he hinted that he feared a return to the Islamic terrorist attacks of the sort that killed scores in the mid-1990's.

White House officials said President Clinton would add a brief stop in Cairo to his Africa trip to discuss the Middle East peace talks with President Hosni Mubarak.

Bahrain Crash Investigated Investigators searched for the cause of a Gulf Air Airbus's crash into the sea off Bahrain on Wednesday, killing all 143 people on board, as grieving relatives of the victims prepared to bury their dead.

American Priest Killed in Kenya The Rev. John Anthony Kaiser, 67, a Roman Catholic who made many enemies among the powerful and corrupt in Kenya for the last 36 years, was found shot to death. Investigators said they suspected murder.

Mission to Congo Uncertain The Security Council is no closer to knowing when, if ever, a United Nations peacekeeping mission can be sent to Congo, after a week of conflicting signals from President Laurent Kabila.

Burmese Dissident Blocked The pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was stopped by the police from traveling outside Yangon. It was the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize laureate's first effort in two years to leave the Myanmar capital.

China Agrees to Free Poet Huang Beiling, a Boston-based Chinese poet arrested in China two weeks ago in connection with a literary journal he edits, will be released and deported to the United States, an American Embassy official said.

Monsoon Flooding in India Torrential rains and raging rivers in the last two months have caused the worst flooding in decades across northern India. And this week, sudden, violent downpours deluged southern India, as well.

Latin America Would Have Priority, Bush Says in Miami Gov. George W. Bush accused the Clinton administration of neglecting Latin American and he pledged to put those countries at the center of his foreign policy agenda. Mr. Bush outlined a way of thinking about the region that put it on a par with American interests in Europe and Asia.

The Republican National Committee released a 30-second television advertisement that sharply criticizes Vice President Al Gore's plan for providing a prescription drug benefit for seniors. It is the first attack commercial of the postconvention presidential campaign.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, making his first solo campaign foray as Mr. Gore's running mate, accused Governor Bush of distorting the Democrats' tax cut proposal, saying it was time for ''an honest debate'' on the subject.

Complaints About Pilot Group A man and a woman at a hotel in Sparks, Nev., said they were verbally and physically assaulted in a hallway on Aug. 19 by a group of men attending the annual convention of the Tailhook Association. Naval officials are investigating. Drunken debauchery and sexual assaults at a convention nine years ago led to resignations, fines and changes in the military's treatment of women.

Asylum for Gay Mexican Man A federal appeals court has ruled that a gay Mexican man who dresses and acts like a woman is entitled to asylum in the United States, expanding the circumstances that immigration officials must consider when foreigners ask to stay in the country. The man had told of repeated assaults and taunts by the Mexican police before he fled to the United States in 1995.
Carl Barks The former Disney artist, whose distinctive Donald Duck renderings and creation of Scrooge McDuck attracted a large following, was 99.

2 More West Nile Victims; City to Intensify Spraying Two elderly women, one from Brooklyn and one from Staten Island, are seriously ill from the West Nile virus, bringing the number of people infected this summer to five. Staten Island has replaced Queens as the hot zone for the disease this year. Officials said the spraying of pesticides would be intensified over the weekend.

Herald Square Makeover The city's Department of Transportation has embarked on the final stage of a reconfiguration that will eliminate a lane of traffic on Broadway, reverse the flow of cars on 33rd Street and create pedestrian plazas below 34th Street.

Indians Seek Bank of Their Own Eleven Indian tribes or tribal corporations from across the country, including the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, have agreed to commit $1 million each to found the nation's largest intertribal bank. The bank, with a plan to focus initially on providing large-scale loans to Indian-owned businesses, is seeking $19 million more in start-up funds.

Arrest in Brooklyn Stable Fire Frank Esposito, 17, of Brooklyn was arrested and charged in the fire that killed 21 horses on the night of June 10. The police said the fire apparently started when Mr. Esposito stopped by the century-old Bergen Beach Stables to smoke marijuana.
Bodies of Drowned Boys Found The bodies of two emotionally disturbed teenagers who disappeared after jumping into the Hudson on Tuesday have been found.

Art Imitates Art A half-ton, eight-foot bronze of Jackie Gleason as Ralph Kramden, New York's most famous fictitious bus driver, will be placed at the Eighth Avenue entrance to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
Woods Way Out Front, Again Tiger Woods shot a nine-under-par 61 to lead the NEC Invitational by seven strokes after two rounds.

A Costly Stock Hoax A false report of upheaval at Emulex, which makes fiber optic equipment, was widely disseminated by news services, sending the company's stock plunging to $45 from $103 in 15 minutes, stripping more than $2 billion from the company's market value and dragging down several other stocks. Trading in Emulex was halted and when it resumed, the share price recovered.
The Dow rose 9.89 points, to 11,192.63, but the Nasdaq fell 10.60 points, to 4,042.68, and the S.& P. 500 slipped 1.85 points, to 1,506.46.

Fed Chief on Globalization Alan Greenspan told a conference of central bankers that pragmatism rather than ideology was driving the international adoption of policies intended to help meet ''the rigors of international competition.'' But he acknowledged a ''deep-seated antipathy toward free market competition'' in some quarters, and warned of a backlash should economic conditions give way to tougher times.

Ford Joins Move to Internet Ford and a council of its 4,200 Ford-brand dealers will set up their own online retailer, FordDirect.com, to help customers find Ford vehicles at fixed prices at dealerships.
Editorials: Two remedies for school failures -- making summer school mandatory, finding qualified teachers; a searching look at Flight 800; real confessions.
